sn7.17:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.
sn7.17:4.2: Now at that time the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Builder was doing some building work in that jungle thicket.
sn7.17:4.3: He saw the Buddha sitting down in meditation posture at the root of a certain sal tree, with his body erect, and mindfulness established right there.
sn7.17:4.4: Seeing this, it occurred to him:
sn7.17:4.5: “I enjoy doing this building work here in the jungle.
sn7.17:4.6: I wonder what the ascetic Gotama enjoys doing?”
sn7.17:4.7: Then Bhāradvāja the Builder went up to the Buddha
sn7.17:5.1: “What kind of work do you do
sn7.17:5.2: as a mendicant in the sal jungle?
sn7.17:6.1: “There’s nothing I need to do in the jungle;
sn7.17:6.2: my jungle’s cut down at the root, it’s withered away.
sn7.17:6.3: With jungle cleared and free of thorns,
sn7.17:6.4: I enjoy being alone in the jungle, having given up dissatisfaction.”
sn7.17:7.1: When he had spoken, the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Builder said to the Buddha:
sn7.17:7.3: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
